questions.text: Tetanus toxin act on which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Tetanus toxin cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein 2 (VAMP2) also known as synaptobrevin.
  • This molecule is necessary for presynaptic binding and release of neurotransmitters.
  • Thus, tetanus toxin prevents transmitter release and effectively blocks inhibitory interneuron discharge which results in unregulated activity in the motor nervous system.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice A: SNAP-25
    • Targeted by botulinum toxin, not tetanus toxin.
    • SNAP-25 is another SNARE protein involved in vesicle fusion at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Choice C: Syntaxin
    • Also a SNARE protein, but not cleaved by tetanus toxin.
    • Botulinum toxin C cleaves syntaxin.
  • Choice D: NSF (N-ethylmaleimide sensitive factor)
    • Involved in disassembling SNARE complexes, but not a target of tetanus toxin.

Key Takeaway:

Tetanus toxin cleaves synaptobrevin (VAMP2), blocking inhibitory neurotransmitter release and causing spastic paralysis.

questions.text: What is duration of short term memory?
questions.solution:
Short term memory lasts for a few seconds to a few minutes at a time but lasts only as long as the person continues to think about the numbers or facts.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice A: 1-4 sec
    • Too short for STM.
    • Sensory memory (iconic or echoic memory) lasts milliseconds to a few seconds, not STM.
  • Choice C: 120-180 sec
    • Too long for STM.
    • Information retained for minutes to hours is part of working memory or short-term consolidation.
  • Choice D: >300 sec
    • This falls into the category of long-term memory (LTM), which is stored permanently.

Key Takeaway:

Short-term memory typically lasts 15-30 seconds unless actively rehearsed.

questions.text: Which of the following substance follows the given transport graph?
questions.solution:
Glucose transport occurs through facilitated diffusion where no energy is needed but transport proteins like carriers are needed. Glucose transporters move the glucose down its concentration gradients from extracellular fluid (ECF) to cytoplasm of the cell.

Other options:

Option B and C: Oxygen and Carbon dioxide is a nonpolar molecule so transport across a lipid cell membrane through simple diffusion.

Option D: Voltage gated channels are gated by alterations in membrane potential. Sodium is transported via voltage gated channels which are simple ion channels acting as transport proteins.

questions.text: Positive lumen gradient for absorption of divalent-ions in thick ascending loop of henle, is by recycling of which of the following ion?
questions.solution:
Positive lumen gradient for absorption of divalent ions in a thick ascending loop of henle is by recycling of potassium (K+) ions.

An Important component of solute reabsorption in the thick ascending limb is the Na+-K+ ATPase pump in the epithelial cell basolateral membranes.

In the thick ascending loop, movement of sodium across the luminal membrane is mediated primarily by a 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium cotransporter (NKCC2). The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the site of action of the loop diuretics furosemide, ethacrynic acid, and bumetanide, all of which inhibit the action of the NKCC2 cotransporter.

There is also significant paracellular reabsorption of cations, such as Mg2+, Ca2+, Na+, and K+, in the thick ascending limb as a result of the slight positive charge of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid.

Although the NKCC2 cotransporter moves equal amounts of catIons and anions into the cell, there is a slight backleak of potassium ions into the lumen, creating a positive charge of about +8 millivolts in the tubular lumen.

questions.text: Decrease in central venous pressure leads to all the following except:
questions.solution:
Decrease in central venous pressure leads to decrease in atrial natriuretic factor.The rate of ANP secretion is proportional to the degree to which the atria are stretched by increases in central venous pressure.

Other options:

Decrease in central venous pressure leads to increase in angiotensin II, sympathetic activation and stimulates thirst.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for peristalisis of segment ahead of food bolus?
questions.solution:
• Anterograde relaxation by vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) is responsible for peristalsis of segment ahead of food bolus.
  • Peristalsis is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen and it occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract from the esophagus to the rectum.
  • Peristalsis is an excellent example of the integrated activity of the enteric nervous system.

questions.text: Discriminative touch sensation is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Meissner's Corpuscle is a relatively large receptor located in the dermal ridges of the glabrous (hairless) skin. This is an elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type Aβ) myelinated sensory nerve fiber. This is a rapidly adapting receptor that senses vibration sensation , tactile discrimination, precise location, tapping and flutter.

Other options:

Incorrect choices explanation :

Option A: Merkel's Disks are the most superficial mechanoreceptor present in the epidermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are slowly adapting a mechanoreceptor that senses touch-pressure.

Option C: Ruffini's Endings are smallest mechanoreceptors present in both glabrous and hairy skin. They are slowly adapting receptors that usually receive the sensation of crude touch.

Option D: Pacinian Corpuscles are mechanoreceptors located in the skin and deep tissues. They are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors capable of receiving high frequency vibration. Therefore, it senses vibration and fine touch and can also sense pressure sensation.

Key Takeaway:

Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for discriminative (fine) touch, flutter sensation, and texture recognition in glabrous skin.

questions.text: A boy presented with intractable diarrhoea after each trip. Stool was rice watery. The organism responsible causes disruption of which of the following in the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario the patient is suffering from cholera. Vibrio cholerae in addition to cholera toxin also releases zonula occludens toxins which alters the permeability of zonula occludens and causes disruption of it in the intestinal epithelium.

Tight junction or Zona occludens form a barrier to the movement of ions and other solutes from one cell to another.

Other options:

Option B: Desmosomes are the adherens junctions where thickened focal areas are formed on both the opposing cell membranes.

Option C: In zonula adherens cell membranes of the adjacent cells are separated by a 15-20 nm wide space which is at focal places obliterated by the dense accumulation of the proteins at the cell surface.

Option D: Gap junctions or the nexus are the channels on the lateral surfaces of the two adjacent cells through which the molecules are exchanged between the cells.

questions.text: Which of the following describes relationship of end diastolic volume to force of contraction?
questions.solution:
• Length-tension relationship describes the relationship of end diastolic volume to force of contraction.
  • This law states that the force of contraction is directly proportional to the initial length of the muscle fiber, within the physiological limit.
  • This is also known as Starling's Law of the heart. The volume of the blood ejected by the ventricle depends on the ventricle at the end of the diastole.
  • The length-tension relationship is implicated to explain the physiological activities of the heart.
  • When an extra amount of blood flows into the ventricles, the cardiac muscle is stretched to a greater length.
  • This stretching causes the muscle to contract with increased force because the actin and myosin filaments are brought to a more nearly optimal degree of overlap for force generation.
  • Therefore, the ventricle, because of its increased pumping, automatically pumps the extra blood into the arteries.

choices.text: Urinary concentration of urea in mg/100ml
Plasma concentration of urea in mg/100ml

questions.text: Clearance is given by UV/P. What does U denote?
questions.solution:
U - here denotes the urinary concentration of urea in mg/100ml.

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice A: Urinary concentration of urea in 24hrs
    • Incorrect because U represents concentration in mg/100ml, not total amount over 24 hours.
    • The 24-hour urine collection is used for measuring total excretion, but clearance is calculated per unit time.
  • Choice C: Plasma concentration of urea in mg/100ml
    • Incorrect because P represents plasma concentration, while U is the urine concentration.
  • Choice D: Rate of urine flow
    • Incorrect because V (not U) represents urine flow rate (ml/min).

Key Takeaway:

U in the clearance formula (C = UV/P) refers to the urinary concentration of the substance (mg/100ml).
